content.question: Nitrogen dioxide, <math alttext="N O 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, is a brown gas produced in high-temperature combustion reactions in air. A portion of the <math alttext="U V visible" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>UV-visible</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> spectra of samples of <math alttext="N O 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> at various partial pressures is shown in the following graph. A. Briefly explain why a spectrophotometer should be set at <math alttext="400 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>400</mn><mtext> nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to measure the pressure of <math alttext="N O 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: Nitrogen dioxide, <math alttext="N O 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, is a brown gas produced in high-temperature combustion reactions in air. A portion of the <math alttext="U V visible" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>UV-visible</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> spectra of samples of <math alttext="N O 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> at various partial pressures is shown in the following graph. A. Briefly explain why a spectrophotometer should be set at <math alttext="400 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>400</mn><mtext> nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to measure the pressure of <math alttext="N O 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Nitrogen dioxide dimerizes to form the colorless gas <math alttext="N 2 O 4 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in a reaction represented by the following balanced equation. <math alttext="2 N O 2, gas, is in equilibrium with N 2 O 4, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><msub><mrow><mtext> NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> A student wishes to determine the equilibrium constant of the dimerization reaction by quantitatively measuring the absorbance of an equilibrium mixture at <math alttext="298 kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>298</mn><mtext> K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The student adds <math alttext="0.327 gram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.327</mn><mtext></mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="N O 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> to a previously evacuated <math alttext="3.0 liter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3.0</mn><mtext> L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> flask at <math alttext="298 kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>298</mn><mtext> K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. B. Calculate the initial pressure of <math alttext="N O 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the flask. (The molar mass of <math alttext="N O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="46.01 grams per mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>46.01</mn><mtext> g/mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.)

C. When equilibrium is reached, the student measures the absorbance of the gas mixture in a <math alttext="1.00 centimeter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.00</mn><mtext> cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cell at <math alttext="400 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>400</mn><mtext> nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and finds it to be <math alttext="A, equals 0.23" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.23</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. A Beer’s law plot of the absorbance at <math alttext="400 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>400</mn><mtext> nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> versus the partial pressure of <math alttext="N O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown in the following graph. i. The student disregards the data point indicated by the arrow, proposing that fingerprints left on the cuvette caused an incorrect absorbance reading. Is this proposal reasonable? Justify your answer. ii. In the Beer’s law plot, the slope of the line is <math alttext="6.1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6.1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Using this information, determine the partial pressure of <math alttext="N O 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the equilibrium mixture. iii. Calculate the equilibrium partial pressure of <math alttext="N 2 O 4 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the reaction mixture. iv. In terms of partial pressures, write the expression for the equilibrium constant, <math alttext="K sub p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and calculate its value.

Dinitrogen tetroxide reacts with water in a reaction represented by the balanced equation below. <math alttext="N 2 O 4, gas, plus H 2 O, liquid, react to produce H N O 2, aqueous, plus H with a positive 1 charge, aqueous, plus N O 3 with a negative 1 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O(</mtext><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>→</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>HNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> D. Justify the claim that the reaction of <math alttext="N 2 O 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> with <math alttext="H 2 O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is a redox reaction by identifying the oxidation number of nitrogen in each of the three nitrogen-containing species.

E. Two solutions of <math alttext="H N O 2, aqueous" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <semantics> <mrow> <msub> <mrow> <mtext>HNO</mtext></mrow> <mn>2</mn> </msub> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaahGart1ev3aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaqGibGaaeOtai aab+eadaWgaaWcbaGaaGOmaaqabaGccaGGOaGaamyyaiaadghacaGG Paaaaa@3F93@ </annotation> </semantics> </math> are prepared using different methods. Solution <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is created by bubbling <math alttext="0.10 mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.10</mn><mtext> </mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="N 2 O 4 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> into <math alttext="1.0 liter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mtext> L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of distilled water. Solution <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is created by dissolving <math alttext="0.10 mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.10</mn><mtext> </mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="H N O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> in distilled water. Explain why the degree of dissociation of the <math alttext="H N O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>HNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> in solution <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is less than that in solution <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 1.A: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate particulate-level properties only.
